History Of Satta King (Matka) Game

The game initially started in Bombay ( Current Mumbai ) in the early 1950s, where people initially used to place bets on the prices of cotton. Ten years later, this game was banned by the new york cotton exchange, and Kalyanji Bhagat thought of an alternative way to keep the Satta Matka business alive by drawing out numbers from a pot (Matka). At a later stage, Ratan Khatri adopted the same idea and used to conduct the Satta Matka game 6 days a week. The Satta Matka game started to gain popularity and frequently used the term Satta king to honor a person's win. In the late 1990s, the Matka business was at its peak, making a turnover of about Rs. 500 crores a month. Due to this, the government, in coordination with the Mumbai police, launched an operation to stop this game and eventually banned it. Currently, most of the Satta Matka game is played online.
